title: New York Fed president defends his bank from criticism over the way it handled turmoil in money market
text:
Bloomberg News/Landov Fed Chairman Jerome Powell walks with New York Fed President John Williams at the central bank’s summer conference in Jackson Hole.

Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams on Monday defended his regional bank from the criticism that it had been slow to react to unsettling conditions in short-term lending markets last week.

“We were prepared for such an event, acted quickly and appropriately, and our actions were successful,” Williams said, in a speech at New York Fed headquarters.

Markets experienced a brief bout of fear last week when the cost to borrow money on a short-term basis suddenly shot up. Institutions often go into the market to borrow cash in return for a loan of Treasurys. Starting last Monday, they found that cash was scarce and that the overnight rate on Treasury repurchase agreements had surged.

This quickly spilled over into other markets. For instance, the Fed’s benchmark federal funds interest rate traded outside the central bank’s preferred range for one day.

It was the first bout of significant market unrest for Williams, who took over as head of the New York Fed in June 2018, after a long career as a Fed economist and head of the regional Fed bank in San Francisco. The reviews of his performance from market participants have not been kind.

Investors said the central bank should have stepped in as soon as last Monday to arrest the surge in overnight borrowing costs.

See: Wall Street raises questions about Fed’s late action on funding squeeze

While defending his bank’s performance, Williams also said he would focus on how banks might have contributed to the problems in the funding markets. “It is ... important that we examine these recent market dynamics and their implications for the liquidity needs in relation to the overall amount of reserves held at the Federal Reserve,” Williams said.

In a Bloomberg television interview Monday, former New York Fed President Bill Dudley came to Williams’s defense. “It’s not one person at the top of the Federal Reserve that does this,” Dud;ey said. “There’s hundreds and hundreds of qualified people who execute monetary policy for the Federal Reserve.”

The Fed might have responded a little sooner but, in the scheme of things, this will end up being seen as a flash in the pan, Dudley said.

“Where are we today? We’re in a good place. Repo rates are now down to where they should be. The federal funds rate is well within its range. So, mission accomplished, as far as I can see,” he said.

Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said last week that the market unrest had no impact on the U.S. economy.

The Fed has been shrinking its balance sheet. That might also have contributed to the market unrest. Powell said the Fed would review its balance-sheet policy at its next meeting.

Dudley said the Fed could build up a buffer by increasing its balance sheet and set up a standing repo facility that banks could tap for funding whenever there is upward pressure on short-term rates.

Late last week, the New York Fed announced it would conduct daily repurchase operations through Oct. 10 to provide temporary injections of liquidity into the market.
